{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} "'''Freedom Flotilla II – Stay Human'''"<ref>{{cite news |last=Bannoura |first=Saed |date=27 June 2011 |url=http://www.aljazeerah.info/News/2011/June/27%20n/German%20activists%20hold%20'solidarity%20flotilla'%20in%20Berlin%20canals.htm |title=German activists hold 'solidarity flotilla' in Berlin canals |work=Al-Jazeerah: Cross-Cultural Understanding |agency=IMEMC News |accessdate=16 August 2011}}</ref> was a [[flotilla]] that planned to break the [[Blockade of the Gaza Strip (2007-present)|maritime blockade]] of the [[Gaza Strip]] by Israel by sailing to Gaza on 5 July 2011. Ultimately, the sailing did not take place.<ref>{{cite news |author=JTA |date=1 July 2011 |title=Flotilla delayed until next week |url=http://www.jewishjournal.com/israel/article/flotilla_delayed_until_next_week_20110701/ |work=Jewish Journal |accessdate=2 July 2011}}</ref>
The flotilla was organized by a coalition of 22 NGOs. Its name refers to the May 2010 [[Gaza Flotilla Raid|Gaza Freedom Flotilla]]. Their stated goal was to end the blockade of Gaza "completely and permanently".<ref>{{cite press release |date=18 June 2011 |url=http://www.freedomflotilla.eu/en/information/3-freedomflotilla-announcements/129-press-release-from-istanbul |title=Press Release from Istanbul |publisher=Freedomflotilla.eu |accessdate=1 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110625001123/http://freedomflotilla.eu/en/information/3-freedomflotilla-announcements/129-press-release-from-istanbul |archivedate=25 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Initially, 10 ships, with 1,000 activists<ref name="AJN_24Jun2011a"/> were set to sail for Gaza, but by 28 June 2011, the [[List of participants of Freedom Flotilla II|number of expected participants]] had decreased to fewer than 300, plus a few dozen journalists, and by 7 July all but a few dozen activists had returned home.<ref name="Katz-2010"/><ref name="Magnezi-28-June-2011">{{cite news |last=Magnezi |first=Aviel |date=28 June 2011 |title=Fewer than 300 join flotilla |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4088464,00.html |work=Ynetnews |location=Tel Aviv |accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref>
The flotilla was publicly opposed by the United States, France, the United Kingdom, Turkey, Canada, the [[Middle East Quartet]] (consisting of the [[European Union]], Russia, the United Nations, and the United States), and [[United Nations Secretary General]] [[Ban Ki-moon]]. It was publicly supported by [[Hamas]].<ref name="cbc.ca">{{cite news |date=2 July 2011 |title=Gaza-bound activists vow to complete trek |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/story/2011/07/03/gaza-flotilla.html |work=CBC World News |accessdate=2 July 2011}}</ref>
Activists on two ships, one in Greece and one in Turkey, found similar damage to their propeller shafts, and claimed that the ships had been sabotaged by Israel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/israel-also-sabotaged-irish-ship-say-gaza-flotilla-organizers-1.370434 |title=Israel also sabotaged Irish ship, say Gaza flotilla organizers |work=Haaretz |location=Israel|accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref> It was reported that the investigation by Turkish authorities on one of the ships determined that there may have been no sabotage at all, and that any damage happened before the boat arrived in Turkey, but these media reports appeared prior to the formal investigation beginning and the Turkish coastguard enquiry has yet to announce its findings. The media reports were disputed by Irish Ship to Gaza, the owner of the vessel.<ref name="apgreece"/><ref name="greece_blocks_boat"/><ref>{{cite web |date=4 July 2011 |title=Sabotage of MV Saoirse |url=http://irishshiptogaza.org/?p=746 |work=Blog archive |publisher=Irish Ship to Gaza |accessdate=5 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707062019/http://irishshiptogaza.org/?p=746 |archivedate=7 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Greece forbade the vessels from leaving its ports, citing safety concerns,<ref name="greek"/> but offered to instead send any humanitarian aid to Gaza in its own vessels, under United Nations supervision. Greece's offer was supported by Israel, the Palestinian Authority, and the United Nations, but rejected by the flotilla activists.<ref name="voareject"/><ref name="bill"/> Subsequently, two flotilla ships, the ''Audacity of Hope'' and ''Tahrir'', disobeyed Greece's orders. They were intercepted by the Greek coast guard, brought back to shore, and a few activists were arrested. Activists responded by occupying the Spanish embassy in Athens.<ref name="sunk"/>
Only the French ship ''Dignité Al Karama'' managed to approach Gaza. They advised the Greek authorities that their destination was the Egyptian port of [[Alexandria]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://alethonews.wordpress.com/2011/07/18/dignite-al-karama-sailing-to-gaza/ |title=Dignité-Al Karama sailing to Gaza |work=Aletho News |date=18 July 2011 |accessdate=22 August 2011}}</ref> and then turned toward Gaza.<ref name="AlJazeera-2011-07-18"/> On 19 July, the ship was intercepted and boarded without incident by Israeli commandos and escorted to the Israeli port of [[Ashdod]].<ref name="BBC-2011-07-19"/>
==Background== [[Image:Gazaseablocade.png|thumb|250px|Gaza Strip naval blockade area, as published by Israel's Ministry of Transport]] After the 2007, [[Fatah-Hamas conflict]], Israel and Egypt closed off their respective borders with Gaza, preventing most goods and nearly all people from going in and out.<ref name="NYT_16June2011a"/>
At the end of May 2010 a flotilla of six ships left from Turkey towards the Gaza Strip. The main purpose of the flotilla, according to its organizers, was to bring humanitarian supplies to the Gaza Strip. On 31 May 2010 the [[Gaza flotilla raid|Israeli navy raided the ships]] some 40 kilometres away from Gaza shores. During the takeover, a violent confrontation occurred in which nine activists were killed on one of the ships and several Israeli soldiers were injured as well as dozens of passengers from several ships. At the end of the operation the ships were seized by the Israeli navy and taken to the port of Ashdod.
Following the 2010 Gaza flotilla raid, international outrage contributed to a shift in Israeli policy. Both Israel and Egypt eased their blockade, letting in more goods over land.<ref name="NYT_16June2011a"/> In June 2010 Egypt decided to open the land crossings between Egypt and the Gaza Strip in order to transfer a minimal amount of supplies.
After the events of the 2011 flotilla raid, organizations from several countries declared their intention to send more ships to break the blockade on Gaza. As a result, the Israeli government announced that the any ships attempting to break the blockade of the Gaza Strip would be arrested.
Opinions on the [[Legal assessments of the Gaza flotilla raid#Legality of blockade|legality]] of Israel's blockade of the Gaza strip, as well as on the use of force in international waters to maintain the blockade, are divided.<ref name="washingtonpost1">{{cite news |last=Lynch |first=Colum |date=1 June 2010 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/06/01/AR2010060102934.html?hpid=topnews |title=Israel's flotilla raid revives questions of international law |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Hirsch |first=Afua |date=1 June 2010 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/law/afua-hirsch-law-blog/2010/jun/01/gaza-freedom-flotilla-international-law |title=Was the Gaza Flotilla Raid Illegal? |work=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref>
On 3 July 2011, the Greek government offered to bring humanitarian aid to Gaza themselves, but Greece's offer was turned down by the activists.<ref>{{cite news |last=Katz |first=Yaakov |date=4 July 2011 |title=Activists reject Greek offer to send flotilla aid |url=http://www.jpost.com/International/Article.aspx?id=227783 |work=Jerusalem Post |accessdate=7 July 2011}}</ref>
==Structure==
===Name=== The flotilla was named in memory of [[Vittorio Arrigoni]], an Italian reporter and activist whose killing by suspected members of a Palestinian [[Salafist jihadism|Salafist]] group in Gaza in April 2011 "left the Palestinian activist community stunned." His favourite expression was "Stay Human".<ref>{{Cite news|last=Schwartz |first=Susan |date=2 June 2011 |title=The Stay Human Flotilla to Gaza |url=http://muslimmedianetwork.com/mmn/?p=8577 |location=Farmington, MI |work=Muslim Observer |accessdate=26 June 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111002214756/http://muslimmedianetwork.com/mmn/?p=8577 |deadurl=no |archivedate=2 October 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref>
===Ships=== Originally it was thought that the [[MV Mavi Marmara|MV ''Mavi Marmara'']] would lead the flotilla, but in mid-June, IHH announced that the ship would be unable to sail due to technical issues.<ref name="NYT_17June2011a">{{cite news |last=Arsu |first=Sebnem |date=17 June 2011 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/18/world/europe/18briefs-Turkey.html |title=Turkey: Aid Ship Won't Join Flotilla |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref> As of 10 July 2011, the following ships had planned on sailing to reach Gaza:<ref name="Hass-2011"/>

===Participants=== {{Main|List of participants of Freedom Flotilla II}} Initially, 10 ships, with 1,000 activists from 20 countries<ref name="AJN_24Jun2011a"/> were said to be set to sail for Gaza from various European ports, with humanitarian aid,<ref name="NYT_11May2011a">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/12/world/middleeast/12iht-M12-TURK-FLEET.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |title=A Year After Israeli Raid, 2nd Flotilla to Set Sail for Gaza |date=11 May 2011 |first=Susanne |last=Güsten}}</ref> during the last days of June, or few days of July 2011.<ref name="NYT_22June2011a">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/22/world/middleeast/22gaza.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |title=Israel to Allow Building Cargo to Enter Gaza |date=22 June 2011 |first=Ethan |last=Bronner}}</ref> As of 28 June 2011, however, the number of expected participants had decreased to 350, plus a few dozen journalists.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Keinon |first1=Herb |last2=Katz |first2=Yaakov |author3=jpost.com staff |date=30 June 2011 |url=http://www.jpost.com/DiplomacyAndPolitics/Article.aspx?id=227274 |title='Damaged Irish ship won't join flotilla after sabotage' |work=[[Jerusalem Post]] |accessdate=26 October 2011}}</ref> By 7 July, all but a few dozen activists had returned home.<ref>{{cite news |last=Magnezi |first=Aviel |date=7 July 2011 |title=Flotilla activists about to give up? |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4092459,00.html |work=Ynetnews |location=Tel Aviv |accessdate=21 August 2011}}</ref>
===Organizers=== The flotilla was organized by various NGOs:{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Free Gaza Movement]] *Canadian Boat to Gaza *European Campaign to End the Siege on Gaza *[[IHH (Turkish NGO)|IHH Humanitarian Relief Foundation]] *Irish Ship to Gaza *Rumbo a Gaza (Spain) *Ship to Gaza Greece *Ship to Gaza Sweden *The International Committee to Lift the Siege on Gaza *Un bateau français pour Gaza (France) *US Boat to Gaza *[[Free Palestine Movement]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jun/18/all-woman-gaza-freedom-flotilla |title=Hizbullah 'bans' Lebanese singer from all-woman Gaza mission |author=Ian Black |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=18 June 2010 |accessdate=18 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://imemc.org/article/58901/ |title=50 Ships To Join Second Freedom Flotilla |author= |work=IMEMC Agencies |date=16 May 2010 |accessdate=18 March 2018}}</ref>
{{div col end}}
==Events==
===Preparations=== The IHH announced plans for the new flotilla, again led by the MV ''Mavi Marmara'' to depart for Gaza in June 2011. IHH President [[Fehmi Bülent Yıldırım]] said "Even if we sacrifice shahids (martyrs) for this cause, we will be on the side of justice."<ref>{{Cite news |last=Magnezi |first=Aviel |date=18 May 2011 |title=IHH: Mavi Marmara ready for next flotilla |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4070717,00.html |work=Ynetnews |location=Tel Aviv |accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref> In June 2011, the IHH conveyed a message to the Israeli government through Turkish Jews that the organization was not interested in another clash with Israel, and a proposal that the ships be inspected in a third-party country, such as Cyprus, before being allowed into Gaza.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Eichner |first=Itamar |date=14 June 2011 |title=IHH sends 'no violence' message to Israel |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4081829,00.html |work=Ynetnews |location=Tel Aviv |accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref>
Plans for the new flotilla were met with international opposition. United Nations Secretary-General [[Ban Ki-moon]] urged Mediterranean governments to discourage the new flotilla and send aid through "legitimate crossings and established channels",<ref>{{Cite news |author=Reuters |date=27 May 2010 |title=UN chief: Discourage new Gaza flotilla |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4074876,00.html |work=Ynetnews |location=Tel Aviv |accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref> the United States warned against the flotilla reportedly considered asking Turkey to host a peace summit between Israel and the [[Palestinian National Authority|Palestinian Authority]] provided that it stop it,<ref>{{Cite news |author=Ynet |title=US: Peace summit instead of flotilla |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4077939,00.html |work=Ynetnews |location=Tel Aviv |date=3 June 2011 |accessdate=24 June 2011}}</ref> and Canada warned its nationals not to participate in the flotilla and called it "provocative".<ref>{{Cite news |author=AFP |date=30 May 2011 |title=Canada warns citizens: Avoid Gaza flotilla |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4076037,00.html |work=Ynetnews |location=Tel Aviv |accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref> Turkey urged activists to reconsider the need for a flotilla in light of the newly opened [[Rafah crossing]], but also urged Israel to act wisely and avoid past mistakes.<ref>{{cite news |last=Greenberg |first=Hanan |date=15 June 2011 |title=Navy gears for Turkish flotilla |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4082355,00.html |work=Ynetnews |location=Tel Aviv |accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref>
Several Dutch journalists who were due to travel in the flotilla backed out in late June, accusing the organizers of non-transparency, particularly with regard to their relations with [[Hamas]], restrictiveness, dishonesty and "shocking" gullibility. Journalist Eric Beauchemin said, "never have I seen a more closed organization. When we would ask critical questions they would accuse us of being unprofessional. Restrictions were imposed on us that hadn't been agreed upon beforehand."<ref>{{cite news |last=van de Poll |first=Wilfred |date=29 June 2011 |url=http://www.trouw.nl/tr/nl/4492/Nederland/article/detail/2459749/2011/06/29/Pers-vertrouwt-Gazaboot-niet.dhtml |title=Pers vertrouwt Gazaboot niet |language=Dutch |work=Trouw.nl |accessdate=10 July 2011 |postscript=;}} translated in {{cite web |url=http://www.ngo-monitor.org/article.php?viewall=yes&id=3433 |title=Press doesn't trust Gaza-boat |work=[[NGO Monitor]] |date=30 June 2011 |accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref>
In France, a ship purchased for the flotilla was prevented from sailing after being denied permission to dock in [[Marseille]]. The move followed intense political pressure by the Jewish community on members of [[Parliament of France|Parliament]], political parties, and organizations, which in turn pressured insurance companies and authorities.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Medzini |first=Ronen |date=15 June 2011 |title=French flotilla ship won't sail |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4082772,00.html |work=Ynetnews |location=Tel Aviv |accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref> A day before, the IHH had announced that was rethinking its participation in the flotilla and might withdraw from the initiative.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Magnezi |first=Aviel |date=15 June 2011 |title=IHH may not take part in flotilla |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4082482,00.html |work=Ynetnews |location=Tel Aviv |accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref> On 17 June, İHH announced that they are still part of the flotilla movement, though the ''Mavi Marmara'' pulled out from the flotilla because, according to Yıldırım, president of IHH, "after the damage caused to the ''Mavi Marmara'' [last year], we are not in a position to go to sea".<ref name="ihhff2">{{cite web |title=Freedom Flotilla II to go ahead as planned |url=http://www.ihh.org.tr/ii-ozgurluk-filosu-yoluna-devam-ediyor/en/ |location=Istanbul |publisher=IHH |accessdate=26 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110627181353/http://www.ihh.org.tr/ii-ozgurluk-filosu-yoluna-devam-ediyor/en/ |archivedate=27 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}<br />• {{cite news|last=Buck|first=Tobias|title=Turkish flagship pulls out of Gaza flotilla|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/ec4ab2dc-98eb-11e0-bd66-00144feab49a.html#axzz1RE42WnpH|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=The Financial Times|date=17 June 2011}}</ref>
===Initial leg=== Two of the vessels taking part in the flotilla set sail from the French island of [[Corsica]] to Greece, to meet up with the other vessels. The vessels docked in [[Piraeus]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Ya'ar |first=Chana |date=26 June 2011 |url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/145187 |title=Flotilla Vessels Sail from France |work=Arutz Sheva |accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref> However, the French vessel ''Dignité – Al Karama'' did not dock, and proceeded directly towards the Gaza Strip.<ref>{{cite news |last=Magnezi |first=Aviel |date=29 June 2011 |title=Gaza-bound flotilla underway |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4088843,00.html |work=Ynetnews |location=Tel Aviv |accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref>
===Vessels damaged=== On 27 June 2011, activists announced that they had discovered damage to two of the vessels, the ''Juliano'' and MV ''Saoirse''. Both the vessels had their propellers and pipes leading to their engines damaged. According to Flotilla spokesman [[Dror Feiler]], there was no direct evidence Israel was involved,<ref>{{cite news |last1=Keinon |first1=Kerb |last2=Katz |first2=Yaakov |date=30 June 2011 |title='Damaged Irish ship won't join flotilla after sabotage' |url=http://www.jpost.com/DiplomacyAndPolitics/Article.aspx?id=227274 |work=Jerusalem Post |accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref> and he estimated the damage would take several days to repair. Other flotilla organizers suspected that the damage was the result of a sabotage operation by Israeli naval divers, and demanded that the Greek police and port authorities provide security for the vessels. Some activists announced that they themselves planned to guard the vessels.<ref>{{cite news |last=Pfeffer |first=Anshel |date=29 June 2011 |title=Gaza flotilla organizers demand Greek police provide security for ships |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/gaza-flotilla-organizers-demand-greek-police-provide-security-for-ships-1.370132 |work=Haaretz |accessdate=30 June 2011}}<br />• {{cite news |last=Magnezi |first=Aviel |date=28 June 2011 |title=Organizers: Israeli divers harmed flotilla ship |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4088583,00.html |work=Ynetnews |location=Tel Aviv |accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref> On 29 June, the MV ''Saoirse'' sustained damage while docked in Turkey. Activists claimed that the damage was caused by Israeli divers, who were able to avoid detection by guards stationed on the vessel.<ref>{{cite news |last=Magnezi |first=Aviel |date=30 June 2011 |title=Activists: Israel sabotaged Irish vessel too |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4089151,00.html |work=Ynetnews |location=Tel Aviv |accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref>
A number of passengers on the flotilla said they had been mugged on the streets near the port and had mobile phones stolen, and that suspicious "fishermen" had been sighted near the ships, loitering without bait or buckets, by waters that are known to be contaminated.<ref>{{cite news |author1=Haaretz |last2=Hass |first2=Amira |date=30 June 2011 |title=Israel also sabotaged Irish ship, say Gaza flotilla organizers |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/israel-also-sabotaged-irish-ship-say-gaza-flotilla-organizers-1.370434 |work=Haaretz |accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref>
Israel flatly rejected the accusations as "paranoid" and accused the activists of "living in a [[James Bond]] film."<ref name="greek"/>
Selcuk Unal, a spokesman for the Turkish Foreign Ministry, said that an investigation by Turkish authorities determined that there was no act of sabotage on the Irish ship, which had been docked in the Turkish port of Gocek.<ref name="apgreece"/> These claims have been disputed by Activists who called for an independent investigation into how the MV ''Saoirse'' was damaged.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/irish-group-doubts-independence-of-aid-ship-sabotage-probe-511344.html |title=Irish group doubts independence of aid-ship 'sabotage' probe |work=breakingnews.ie |accessdate=6 July 2011 }}</ref>
Due to the damage, the MV ''Saoirse's'' plans to join the flotilla were cancelled but several Irish activists went to Corfu to join the Italian/Dutch ship, the MV ''Stefano Chiarini''.
The Irish Ship to Gaza campaign later repaired the MV ''Saoirse'' and in November 2011, joined by the Canadian ship, the MV ''Tahrir'', it slipped out of Turkey and sailed for Gaza. This sailing was called the "Freedom Waves to Gaza" flotilla. Both ships were intercepted by Israeli warships some 50 miles from Gaza. Both ships and 27 activists and crew – 14 Irish citizens and 13 Canadian, Australian, US and Greek citizens – were brought by force to Ashdod, imprisoned for a week and then expelled from Israel.{{citation needed|date=October 2012}}
===Greek travel ban=== Greece announced that any vessels bound for Gaza are forbidden from leaving their ports.<ref name="csm-greece"/> Greece emphasized safety concerns and noted that the Secretary General of the United Nations, the European Council, the Middle East Quartet and Greece itself had already urged against participation in the flotilla.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mfa.gr/www.mfa.gr/AuthoritiesAbroad/North+America/USA/EmbassyWashington/Articles/en-US/Foreign+Ministry+Announcement+regarding+Greece%E2%80%99s+intention+to+undertake+the+task+of+transporting+hum.htm |title=Foreign Ministry Announcement regarding Greece's intention to undertake the task of transporting humanitarian aid |location=Washington, D.C. |publisher=Embassy Of Greece |date=3 July 2011 |accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref>
Greece offered to transfer the cargo onto Greek ships, and transport humanitarian aid through established aid channels, as requested by the UN Secretary General.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Ben-David |first1=Calev |last2=Petrakis |first2=Maria |date=3 July 2011 |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-07-03/greece-offers-to-transfer-aid-from-detained-flotilla-to-gaza.html |title=Greece Offers to Transfer Aid From Detained Flotilla to Gaza |work=Bloomberg |accessdate=3 July 2011}}</ref> The offer was supported by Israel, the Palestinian Authority and the United Nations, but rejected by the flotilla activists.<ref name="voareject"/><ref name="bill"/>
====Violations==== On 1 July, the American-manned flotilla boat ''Audacity of Hope'', which was not carrying any aid, sailed from [[Perama]] in violation of this Greek ban. It was intercepted after about ten minutes by an armed [[Hellenic Coast Guard]] boat and two Zodiac speedboats. An hours-long standoff ensued, with the coast guard initially trying to persuade the boat to turn back. Eventually, the boat was boarded by armed coast guard personnel and escorted to a Greek naval facility.<ref name="greek"/><ref name="bill"/><ref>{{cite news |last=Torchia |first=Christopher |date=2 July 2011 |url=http://www.boston.com/news/world/europe/articles/2011/07/02/greeks_turn_back_us_protesters_bound_for_blockaded_gaza/ |title=Greeks turn back US protesters bound for blockaded Gaza |work=The Boston Globe |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=2 July 2011}}</ref> Greek authorities arrested the American captain of the boat, John Klusmire, and held him on charges of endangering the lives of the boat's passengers, which is a felony, and of trying to leave port without permission. Activists responded by launching a [[hunger strike]]. Klusmire was released from custody on 5 July, but the charges against him were not dropped.<ref name="apgreece"/><ref name="sunk"/><ref name="haspanish"/><ref name="apreleases"/> "Only a fool thought we'd get to Gaza given what happened last year. We knew we'd be stopped," said Henry Norr, an activist on the boat.<ref>{{cite news |last=Bender |first=Kristin J. |date=8 July 2011 |title=Activist talks about failed mission to reach the Gaza Strip |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/breaking-news/ci_18442144 |work=Mercury News |location=San Jose, CA }}{{registration required}}</ref>
On 4 July, the mainly Canadian-manned ''Tahrir'' sailed from [[Crete]] in violation of the ban. It did so without its original Greek crew on board, and instead with "international volunteers" piloting the boat. Canadian Soha Kneen and Australian Michael Coleman were arrested after they used [[kayak]]s to surround a Greek coast guard vessel pursuing the boat. The coast guard vessel caught up to the ''Tahrir'' after about 15 minutes. Passengers attempted to protect the wheelhouse by draping it with netting and blocking doorways by sitting in front of them and linking arms. The ''Tahrir'' was sprayed with water cannons, boarded by armed officers, and towed back to port. One activist claimed that two officers boarded the boat, and one had a pistol drawn as he approached the boat's wheelhouse to take control. Canadian citizen Sandra Ruch, who was responsible for the boat, was arrested on charges of illegally sailing without permission. Fifty other passengers were detained by the Greek coastal authority.<ref name="greece_blocks_boat"/><ref name="braced"/> Activists claimed that the coast guard vessel rammed the boat against a cement pier and demanded that it be fixed immediately at Greece's expense.<ref name="bill"/><ref name="apreleases"/><ref>{{cite news |last=Chai |first=Carmen |date=5 July 2011 |url=https://vancouversun.com/news/Canadians+freed+after+flotilla+attempts+leave+Greece+Gaza/5052446/story.html |title=Canadians freed after flotilla attempts to leave Greece for Gaza |work=Vancouver Sun |accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref> Activists Soha Kneen and Michael Coleman were tried and found guilty of obstructing the interception of the ''Tahrir'', and were sentenced to 30 days in prison. Both had their sentences suspended and were released, but were fined 246 Euros in court costs.<ref>{{cite news |last=Rankin |first=Jim |date=6 July 2011 |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/world/article/1020539--kayaktivists-from-gaza-flotilla-found-guilty-but-released?bn=1 |title='Kayaktivists' from Gaza flotilla found guilty but released |work=The Star |location=Toronto |accessdate=11 July 2011}}</ref>
In the early morning of 5 July, the French yacht ''Dignité – Al Karama'', carrying eight passengers, evaded the Greek coast guard and left a port near Athens, but turned back on its own after several hours. Reportedly, the activists aboard the vessel did not want to be the only ones sailing to the Gaza Strip.<ref name="sunk"/><ref name="haspanish"/><ref name="braced"/> Later, the vessel attempted to depart again in defiance of the Greek ban, but was stopped and taken to the port of [[Sitia]] on the island of [[Crete]]. Greek authorities said that during these events the yacht collided with a Greek coast guard vessel and damaged it.<ref>{{cite news |last=jpost.com staff |date=17 July 2011 |title='Gaza-bound flotilla yacht leaves Greece, sails to Egypt' |url=http://www.jpost.com/DiplomacyAndPolitics/Article.aspx?id=229670 |work=Jerusalem Post |accessdate=21 August 2011}}</ref>
On 5 July, about 20 Spanish activists from the ship ''Guernica'' occupied the Spanish embassy in Athens to protest the Greek travel ban.<ref name="sunk"/><ref name="braced"/>
===Activist withdrawal=== On 7 July 2011 most of the activists withdrew from the initiative and left Greece for home. Only a few dozen remained to try to convince the Greek government to end its travel ban.<ref name="Katz-2010"/>
===Journey of the ''Dignité Al Karama''=== [[File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - Free Gaza Flotilla Participant Accepts Food From IDF Soldier.jpg|thumb|250px|IDF soldiers giving food to ''Dignite Al Karama'' passengers following the takeover]] On 16 July, the French yacht ''Dignité Al Karama'' left the Greek island of [[Kastellorizo]] after informing Greek authorities that its destination was the Egyptian port of [[Alexandria]].<ref name="egypt"/> Instead, the vessel headed for Gaza. Aboard the yacht were 16 people, including three crew members and journalists from [[Al Jazeera]], as well as [[Amira Hass]], an Israeli journalist from ''[[Haaretz]]''.<ref name="AlJazeera-2011-07-18"/><ref>{{cite news |date=18 July 2011 |title=Freedom Flotilla Update: Dignité-Al Karama will be arriving in Gaza any minute now |url=http://english.pnn.ps/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=10466&Itemid=56 |work=Palestine News Network |accessdate=22 August 2011}}</ref>
''Dignité Al Karama'' was stopped by the [[Israeli Navy]] about 65 kilometers off the coast of Gaza, in international waters, after ignoring warnings that it was approaching the Gaza blockade line and must change course for either [[Ashdod]] or Egypt. The yacht was surrounded by at least three Israeli warships and boarded by [[Shayetet 13]] naval commandos, who took over the vessel, arrested the passengers, and transferred them to a warship. The operation was conducted without any resistance from the passengers or use of violence by the commandos.<ref>{{cite news |last=Chai |first=Carmen |date=19 July 2011 |title=Canadian among activists intercepted by Israel on Gaza-bound ship |url=http://www2.canada.com/topics/news/national/story.html?id=5125814 |work=canada.com |accessdate=22 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Amir |first=Ahmed |date=19 July 2011 |title=Israeli forces take over Gaza-bound boat; no resistance reported |url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-07-19/world/israel.gaza.flotilla_1_free-gaza-movement-gaza-coast-gaza-bound?_s=PM:WORLD |work=CNN |accessdate=22 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110829162856/http://articles.cnn.com/2011-07-19/world/israel.gaza.flotilla_1_free-gaza-movement-gaza-coast-gaza-bound?_s=PM%3AWORLD |archivedate=29 August 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The vessel was towed to [[Ashdod]] port and searched. No weapons or humanitarian aid were found on board.<ref name="BBC-2011-07-19"/><ref>{{cite news |last=Hadad |first=Shmulik |date=19 July 2011 |title=French ship enters Ashdod Port |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4097577,00.html |work=Ynetnews |location=Tel Aviv |accessdate=21 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Greenberg |first=Hanan |date=19 July 2011 |title=Navy stops French flotilla ship |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4097247,00.html |work=Ynetnews |location=Tel Aviv |accessdate=21 August 2011}}</ref> The passengers were taken to Ashdod, where [[Haaretz]] journalist [[Amira Hass]] was released. The remaining 15 passengers were transferred to [[Holon]], where they were interviewed by Immigration Authority personnel and signed documents stipulating that they would leave the country within 72 hours, before being deported.<ref>{{cite news|date=20 July 2011 |url=http://www.arabia.msn.com/News/MiddleEast/AFP/2011/July/7669619.aspx |title=Flotilla activists to be deported: Israel |work=MSN Arabia |agency=AFP |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6173b2Wzh?url=http://www.arabia.msn.com/News/MiddleEast/AFP/2011/July/7669619.aspx |archivedate=21 August 2011 |deadurl=no |accessdate=21 August 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref>
The Paris-based organisers described the Israeli naval interception as "an act of violence and an illegal act," and as "a new act of piracy against harmless people".<ref>{{cite news |author=AFP |date=19 July 2011 |title=Israeli navy seizes Gaza-bound French yacht |url=http://gulfnews.com/news/region/palestinian-territories/israeli-navy-seizes-gaza-bound-french-yacht-1.840215 |work=gulfnews.com |accessdate=22 August 2011}}</ref>
==Reactions==
===Israel=== Israeli officials stated that the flotilla's main purpose was to cause a provocation<ref name="jpost1">{{cite news |date=1 July 2011 |last=Gordon |first=Evelyn |url=http://www.jpost.com/DiplomacyAndPolitics/Article.aspx?id=227412 |title=PM: We have right to work against 'provocation flotilla' |work=The Jerusalem Post |accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> which was designed to serve Hamas's military objectives.<ref name="jpost2">{{cite news |author=staff |date=30 June 2011 |title=Edelstein: Hamas member in flotilla shows intent to provoke |url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=227349 |work=Jerusalem Post |accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
Israeli authorities said that they wish to avoid clashes with the activists, and promised flotilla organizers that if they dock at the Israeli port of [[Ashdod]], humanitarian aid would be delivered by Israel directly to Gaza.<ref name="Ravid-27-June-2011">{{cite news |last=Ravid |first=Barak |date=27 June 2011 |title=Gaza flotilla organizers: Israel is pressuring Greece to halt ships' departure |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/gaza-flotilla-organizers-israel-is-pressuring-greece-to-halt-ships-departure-1.369851 |work=Haaretz |accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref> It warned the flotilla organizers that if they were to attempt to break the blockade, it would intercept the ships and that Israeli forces would defend themselves if they were attacked.<ref name="nyt28"/> To deal with any casualties that could result from a naval interception from the flotilla, the Israeli Navy converted the mess halls on two vessels into operating rooms fully equipped for surgery, and planned for them to feature a full medical staff, including surgeons and anesthesiologists. [[Medevac]] helicopters were also planned be at hand in case any of the injured needed to be evacuated to hospitalized in Israel, and [[Medical Corps (Israel)|Medical Corps]] personnel were to be deployed at the port of [[Ashdod]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Greenberg |first=Hanan |date=30 June 2011 |title=Navy to deploy 'floating ORs' |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4089605,00.html |work=Ynetnews |location=Tel Aviv |accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref>
A top Israeli naval officer{{Who|date=July 2011}} warned that Israel would prevent the ships from breaking its [[2007–present blockade of the Gaza Strip|blockade on Gaza]] at all costs, and that Israel would again use force if required, including boarding the ships and confronting the activists. Brig. Gen. Yoav Mordechai added, "There is an unequivocal directive from the government to enforce the naval blockade that is recognized by international law, and we will not allow it to be broken."<ref name="NYT_16June2011a"/> The [[Israel Defense Forces]] (IDF) began training personnel for future flotillas. In addition to [[Shayetet 13]] commandos, other naval and special forces units were also drilled to participate. IDF Chief of Staff [[Gabi Ashkenazi]] announced that Israel may deploy snipers to minimize troop casualties on the next flotilla.<ref>{{cite news |last=Harel |first=Amos |date=12 August 2010 |title=Ashkenazi: Next time, IDF will use snipers to halt Gaza-bound flotillas |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/ashkenazi-next-time-idf-will-use-snipers-to-halt-gaza-bound-flotillas-1.307435 |work=Haaretz |accessdate=24 June 2011}}</ref> The IDF also announced that attack dogs from [[Unit Oketz]] would be deployed before soldiers to neutralize threats.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Greenberg |first=Hanan |date=7 October 2010 |title=Dogs to be used in next flotilla raid |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3966094,00.html |work=Ynetnews |location=Tel Aviv |accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref> In June 2011, the IDF released a video showing naval forces practicing an interception of the flotilla. The footage showed the use of high-powered water cannons aimed at vessels simulating flotilla ships, along with other means.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Greenberg |first=Hanan |date=16 July 2010 |title=Watch: Navy's flotilla drill |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4083264,00.html |work=Ynetnews |location=Tel Aviv |accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref>
On 19 June 2011, [[Eli Marom]], Commander of the Israeli Navy, was quoted as calling the flotilla a "hate flotilla".<ref>{{cite news |last=Pfeffer |first=Anshel |date=19 June 2011 |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/israel-navy-commander-hate-flotilla-to-gaza-must-be-stopped-1.368579 |title=Israel Navy commander: 'Hate flotilla' to Gaza must be stopped |work=Haaretz |accessdate=19 June 2011}}</ref>
Israeli military sources told Israeli newspapers on 27 June 2011 that some radical elements among flotilla members intended to kill soldiers who tried to board their vessels, and had equipped themselves with bags of sulfur to throw at soldiers. Multiple newspapers reported the statements.<ref>{{cite news |last=Greenberg |first=Hanan |date=27 June 2011 |title=IDF fears flotilla activists will try to kill soldiers |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4088082,00.html |work=Ynetnews |location=Tel Aviv |accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref><ref name="JP_28June2011_IDF_Sulphur_Claim">{{cite news |last1=Katz |first1=Yaakov |date=28 June 2011 |url=http://www.jpost.com/Defense/Article.aspx?ID=226885&R=R1 |newspaper=Jerusalem Post |title=IDF: Some flotilla activists planning to kill soldiers |accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref> Alex Fishman, dean of Israeli military correspondents, criticized these claims and said "There isn't a shred of substance to the report that extremist elements will put up violent resistance to IDF soldiers aboard the flotilla. Neither is there any clear information regarding deadly weapons on any of the ships". He said that it can be assumed that this is considered a possibility by defense forces, along with many other scenarios, but was improperly turned into a definitive fact.<ref group="text" name="JP_29June2011_Hysteria_Hasbara_Flotilla">{{cite news |last=Derfner |first=Larry |date=29 June 2011 |title=Hysteria, hasbara, and the flotilla |url=http://www.jpost.com/Opinion/Columnists/Article.aspx?ID=227181&R=R1 |work=Jerusalem Post |accessdate=30 June 2011}} This article also reports that Israel's most widely read newspaper, ''[[Yedioth Ahronoth]]'', wrote ( in Hebrew ) of the claim, "There isn't a shred of substance to the report that extremist elements will put up violent resistance to IDF soldiers aboard the flotilla. Neither is there any clear information regarding deadly weapons on any of the ships. It can be assumed that this is considered a possibility – along with many other scenarios and possibilities that come up in brainstorming sessions among military and intelligence officials preparing for the flotilla. But when a possibility such as this gets turned into a fact within the context of the Israeli hasbara campaign – this can boomerang and show Israel to be lacking in credibility."</ref> Anonymous Israeli cabinet members described this information as "political spin", saying that information concerning violent resistance had not been presented to them. However, Strategic Affairs Minister [[Moshe Ya'alon]] later said that reports from army sources that flotilla participants were planning lethal violence were accurate.<ref>{{cite news |author=jpost.com staff |date=29 June 2011 |title=Ya'alon: Flotilla participants will try to harm soldiers |url=http://www.jpost.com/Defense/Article.aspx?id=227159 |work=Jerusalem Post |accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref> Similarly, Israel's Prime Minister's Office replied that the materials issued by the IDF spokesman are based on reliable intelligence assessments.<ref group="text" name="YediothAhronoth_29June2011_Netanyahu_IDF_spin">{{cite news |url=http://www.nrg.co.il/online/1/ART2/254/840.html |last=Brdnstein |first=Eli |date=29 June 2011 |title=גורם מדיני: המידע המודיעיני סביב המשט – ספין של נתניהו |language=Hebrew |trans-title=Political factor: the intelligence around the flotilla – Netanyahu's spin |work=[[Yedioth Ahronoth]] |accessdate=30 June 2011 |quote={{lang|he|שרים בקבינט זועמים על כך שהמידע שפרסם צה'ל, לפיו ספינות המשט יעשו דרכן לחופי ישראל כשעל סיפונן חומרים כימיים, לא הובא בפניהם ומזהירים מפני 'היסטריית הסברה סביב המשט'. גורם מדיני אמר: 'מתגבר החשש לספין של נתניהו. שום דבר מהמידע שהופץ לתקשורת לא הובא בפנינו'. לשכת רה'מ מסרה: 'החומר שהוצא על ידי דובר צה'ל אושר על ידי כל גורמי המודיעין'}} [Cabinet ministers are furious that the information issued by the IDF, about which ships will make their way off the coast of Israel with chemical substances aboard, was not brought to them and warned against 'hysterical propaganda about the flotilla.' A diplomatic source said: 'Do not be afraid of Netanyahu's spin. None of the information circulated in the media was brought before us.' The Prime Minister's office said: 'The material issued by the IDF Spokesman was confirmed by all intelligence agencies']}}.</ref>
On the same day, Israel's Government Press Office issued a letter to foreign journalists, warning them that participating in the upcoming flotilla sailing to Gaza could result in them being barred from Israel for up to 10 years. The letter was signed by GPO director Oren Helman.<ref>{{cite news |author=Haaretz |date=26 June 2011 |title=Israel warns foreign journalists: Joining Gaza flotilla is illegal |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/israel-warns-foreign-journalists-joining-gaza-flotilla-is-illegal-1.369684 |work=Haaretz |accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> The decision was rescinded by Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] the following day, along with a statement that journalists would be invited onto Israeli naval vessels. The [[Foreign Press Association]] welcomed the reversal.<ref>{{cite news |last=Izikovich |first=Gili |date=28 June 2011 |title=Netanyahu rescinds decision to sanction journalists on board Gaza flotilla |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/netanyahu-rescinds-decision-to-sanction-journalists-on-board-gaza-flotilla-1.369941 |work=Haaretz |accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref>
On 27 June Israeli Foreign Minister [[Avigdor Lieberman]] stated that [[List of participants of Freedom Flotilla II|flotilla participants]] are "terror activists, seeking to create provocation and looking for blood", and that Israel plans to "deal with the flotilla properly". He added that the majority of those who had planned to join the flotilla now understand that those who wish to help can do this through legal means.<ref>{{cite news |author=staff |date=28 June 2011 |url=http://www.jpost.com/DiplomacyAndPolitics/Article.aspx?ID=226886&R=R1 |title=FM: Flotilla participants are blood-seeking terrorists |work=Jerusalem Post |accessdate=29 June 2011}}</ref>
On 28 June, a YouTube video of a man called "Marc" who claims to be an activist denied from boarding the flotilla on account of his homosexuality was exposed to be a hoax. The man in the video was discovered to be Omer Gershon, an Israeli entrepreneur and public relations expert. The video was tweeted by an intern in Prime Minister Netanyahu's office. The intern said he did not know that the video was a hoax, and that he posted the video on his own private Twitter account, not on behalf of the government.<ref>{{cite news |last=Ravid |first=Barak |date=28 June 2011 |title=Did Netanyahu's office distribute a fake video against Gaza flotilla? |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/did-netanyahu-s-office-distribute-a-fake-video-against-gaza-flotilla-1.370030 |work=Haaretz |accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
===Other governments=== * {{Flagu|Canada}}: Foreign Affairs Minister [[John Baird (Canadian politician)|John Baird]] said, "I strongly urge those wishing to deliver humanitarian goods to the Gaza Strip to do so through established channels. Unauthorized efforts to deliver aid are provocative and, ultimately, unhelpful to the people of Gaza." He added that Canadians should instead donate to the Red Cross/Red Crescent in the Gaza Strip. The department of Foreign Affairs and International Trade said: "The border around the Gaza Strip is under the control of Israeli and Egyptian authorities. Canadians who break the laws of another country are subject to the judicial system of that country. DFAIT can neither offer protection from the consequences of such actions nor override the decisions of local authorities."<ref>{{cite news |last=Solyom |first=Catherine |date=26 June 2011 |url=https://vancouversun.com/news/Canadians+ignore+warnings+board+flotilla+bound+Gaza+Strip/5008853/story.html |title=Canadians ignore warnings, set to board flotilla bound for Gaza Strip |work=Vancouver Sun |accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref> * {{Flagu|Egypt}}: Egypt offered to allow the flotilla to dock at the Egyptian port of El Arish. The cargo would then be transferred overland to Gaza after it has been searched.<ref name="egypt"/><ref>{{Cite news |last1=Katz |first1=Yaakov |last2=Keinon |first2=Herb |date=27 June 2011 |title='Israel, Egypt agree flotilla can unload cargo in El-Arish' |url=http://www.jpost.com/Defense/Article.aspx?id=226713 |work=Jerusalem Post |accessdate=27 June 2011}}</ref> * {{Flagu|France}}: The Foreign Ministry of France strongly denounced the flotilla, calling it a "bad idea that is expected only to increase tension and be a source of conflict". "Last year's events showed that there is a danger that confrontation will result from these initiatives," it said in a statement.<ref>{{cite news |author=UPI |date=30 June 2011 |url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2011/06/30/Another-ship-headed-to-Gaza-damaged/UPI-55371309435411/ |title=Another ship headed to Gaza damaged] |work=UPI |accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref> The French Ambassador to Israel told Israeli authorities that France expected them to "act with a sense of responsibility and moderation". France indicated that it was prepared to provide consular protection to its nationals, and reiterated its position that the Gaza blockade should be lifted.<ref>{{cite web|author=Ministry of Foreign and European Affairs|title=Boarding of the Dignite-Al Karama vessel|date=20 July 2011|accessdate=22 July 2011|url=http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files_156/israel-palestinian-territories_290/palestinian-territories_2156/france-and-the-palestinian-territories_2758/political-relations_6021/boarding-of-the-dignite-al-karama-vessel-20.07.11_16002.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110805000717/http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files_156/israel-palestinian-territories_290/palestinian-territories_2156/france-and-the-palestinian-territories_2758/political-relations_6021/boarding-of-the-dignite-al-karama-vessel-20.07.11_16002.html|archivedate=5 August 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * {{flag|Gaza Strip}}: On 24 June 2011 [[Ismail Haniya]], the [[Hamas]] Prime Minister of the Gaza Strip, was interviewed as saying "The United Nations and all international law organizations should provide protection to the second flotilla that is preparing to sail to the Gaza Strip. The world must stop Israel from intercepting the ships, We believe that it is the right of the foreign activists to arrive in the Gaza Strip, and we condemn any Israeli threats against them. It is obvious that the Israeli occupation is preparing for another crime against them".<ref name="chinadaily_jun_25">{{Cite news|title=Hamas calls for international protection to Gaza-bound aid flotilla|date=24 June 2011|url=http://www1.chinadaily.com.cn/xinhua/2011-06-25/content_3001791.html/|accessdate=25 June 2011}}{{dead link|date=July 2011}}{{cbignore}}</ref> The Hamas government secretary Mohammad Awad has called other countries to support the flotilla, stating that it was a crime to continue imposing the blockade against the Gaza Strip, and that the claims that the blockade has ended are wrong.<ref name="cbc.ca"/> * {{Flagu|Greece}}: The Greek foreign ministry stated that "Greece's positions on the need to lift the Gaza blockade and improve the humanitarian situation in the region are well known", but added that the flotilla "does not deal with the substance of the humanitarian problem in Gaza", and urged Greek citizens as well as Greek-registered vessels not to participate in it.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mfa.gr/www.mfa.gr/AuthoritiesAbroad/North+America/USA/EmbassyWashington/Articles/en-US/Foreign+Ministry+announcement+regarding+the+intention+of+Greek+citizens+to+participate+in+a+flotilla.htm |title=Foreign Ministry announcement regarding the intention of Greek citizens to participate in a flotilla that will attempt to break the Gaza blockade |location=Washington, D.C. |publisher=Embassy Of Greece |date=22 June 2011 <!-- page metadata --> |accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref> The Greek government later made it illegal for ships to sail from Greece to the Gaza Strip, citing safety concerns (see above).<ref>{{cite news |last=Black |first=Phil |date=2 July 2011 |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/07/02/israel.gaza.flotilla/index.html?hpt=hp_t2 |title=Greeks arrest captain of U.S. ship aiming to protest Gaza blockade |work=CNN |accessdate=11 July 2011}}</ref> * {{Flagu|Ireland}}: The [[Tánaiste]] and [[Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade|Minister for Foreign Affairs]], [[Eamon Gilmore]], urged Israel to show restraint and emphasised to the Israeli ambassador that "if the flotilla does sail next week, then Israel must exercise all possible restraint and avoid any use of military force if attempting to uphold their naval blockade. In particular, I would expect that any interception of ships is conducted in a peaceful manner and does not endanger the safety of our citizens or other participants." He also urged ambassador Modai to forward this message to Israeli authorities to avoid any repetition of the violence which marked last year's flotilla. The meeting with the Israeli ambassador was conducted on 23 June.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.merrionstreet.ie/index.php/2011/06/tanaiste-urges-restraint-by-israel-in-relation-to-forthcoming-gaza-flotilla/?cat=3 |title=Tánaiste Urges Restraint by Israel in relation to forthcoming Gaza Flotilla |work=MerrionStreet – Irish Government News Service |accessdate=26 June 2011}}</ref> The [[Taoiseach]], [[Enda Kenny]], speaking in [[Dáil Éireann]], echoed the same call. * {{Flagu|Netherlands}}: Foreign Minister [[Uri Rosenthal]] wrote a letter to the parliament calling on Dutch NGOs not to join the international flotilla headed to the Gaza Strip. He wrote that the cabinet believes that the flotilla will "not make the least contribution to a resolution of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rnw.nl/africa/bulletin/rosenthal-don%E2%80%99t-join-gaza-flotilla |title=Rosenthal: don't join Gaza flotilla |work=Radio Netherlands |date=26 April 2011 |accessdate=30 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629182241/http://www.rnw.nl/africa/bulletin/rosenthal-don%E2%80%99t-join-gaza-flotilla |archivedate=29 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * {{flag|Palestinian Authority}}: [[Mahmoud Abbas]], President of the Palestinian National Authority and Chairman of the PLO, described Greece's plan to transfer humanitarian aid through established channels as positive, and expressed his support for it.<ref>{{cite news |last=Shalom |first=François |date=4 July 2011 |url=https://montrealgazette.com/news/Flotilla+will+find+Gaza+Canadian+delegation+says/5044281/story.html |title=Flotilla will find a way to Gaza, Canadian delegation says |work=The Gazette |location=Montreal |agency=AFP |accessdate=4 July 2011}}</ref> * {{Flagu|United Kingdom}}: On 29 June 2011, British deputy Foreign Minister, [[Alistair Burt]] stressed that while the UK was very concerned about the situation in Gaza, it did not think the delivery of aid via such a provocative route was appropriate.<ref>{{cite news |last=Ravid |first=Barak |date=28 June 2011 |title=Britain's Mideast minister: It is unwise to challenge Israel with a flotilla to Gaza |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/britain-s-mideast-minister-it-is-unwise-to-challenge-israel-with-a-flotilla-to-gaza-1.370093 |work=Haaretz |accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref> * {{Flagu|United States}}: The U.S. State Department warned Americans taking part in the flotilla that they may violate U.S. civil and criminal statue against delivering material support to terrorist organizations, and may face prosecution.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Ben-David |first=Calev |date=28 Jun 2011 |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-06-28/u-s-lawmakers-say-americans-in-gaza-flotilla-may-be-prosecuted.html |title=U.S. Lawmakers Say Americans in Gaza Flotilla May Be Prosecuted |work=Bloomberg |accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref> In a travel warning, the State Department further advised U.S. citizens that they could face arrest, prosecution and deportation by Israel if they join the flotilla.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/US-Warns-Americans-Against-Joining-Gaza-Aid-Flotilla-124393009.html |title=US Warns Americans Against Joining Gaza Aid Flotilla |work=Voice of America |date=22 Jun 2011 |accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref> State Department spokesperson Victoria Nuland said "Groups that seek to break Israel's maritime blockade of Gaza are taking irresponsible and provocative actions that risk the safety of their passengers. We urge all those seeking to provide such assistance to the people of Gaza...not to participate in actions like the planned flotilla."<ref>{{Cite news |author=Reuters |url=https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2011/06/24/us/politics/politics-us-israel-usa-flotilla.html?_r=2&ref=politics |title=U.S. Warns Against New Gaza Flotilla Plans |work=The New York Times |accessdate=24 June 2011}}</ref> The U.S. Ambassador to the UN, [[Susan Rice]], said that "there are distinct mechanisms to deliver goods to Gaza and there are no justifications to sail directly to Gaza."<ref>{{cite news |last=Shamir |first=Shlomo |date=21 April 2011 |title=Israel: New Gaza flotilla has ties to Hamas, terrorist organizations |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/israel-new-gaza-flotilla-has-ties-to-hamas-terrorist-organizations-1.357416 |work=Haaretz |accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref> Texas Governor [[Rick Perry]] showed his concern regarding the flotilla by asking the [[U.S. attorney general]] to "aggressively pursue all available legal remedies to enjoin and prevent these illegal actions, and to prosecute any who may elect to engage in them in spite of your pre-emptive efforts" referring to any Americans who participate.<ref>{{cite news |author=Associated Press |date=29 June 2011 <!-- page metadata --> |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/texas-gov-rick-perry-urges-us-attorney-general-to-act-against-pro-palestinian-protesters/2011/06/29/AGZawFrH_story.html |title=Texas Gov. Rick Perry urges US attorney general to act against pro-Palestinian protesters |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=11 July 2011}}</ref>
===Supranational organizations=== * The [[Middle East Quartet]], consisting of the [[European Union]], Russia, the United Nations and the United States, said it "urges restraint and calls on all Governments concerned to use their influence to discourage additional flotillas, which risk the safety of their participants and carry the potential for escalation. It urged those wishing to deliver goods to Gaza to do so through "established channels," which include Israeli and Egyptian crossings.<ref>{{cite news |last=Nellis |first=Demetris |date=2 July 2011 |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hl-q1Q4w8OEX1RLeESwixgDfprZg?docId=550ab6515d1f4a9e8aa952b703304a03 |title=Greece arrests Gaza-bound boat captain |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|United Nations}}: On 27 May 2011, UN Chief Ban Ki-moon asked for all governments to seek to discourage such flotillas. He also said that aid should go through legitimate and established channels, and called on all parties to 'act responsibly' such to avoid another violent incident.<ref name="Worsnip-2011">{{Cite news |last=Worsnip |first=Patrick |date=27 May 2011 |title=Ban Ki-moon urges governments to discourage new Gaza convoy |work=Reuters |url=https://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFTRE74Q68K20110527 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160310134608/https://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFTRE74Q68K20110527 |archivedate=10 March 2016 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
===Non-governmental organizations=== [[Shurat HaDin]], an NGO based in Israel, delayed or blocked several of the vessels by legal methods, including warning insurance companies that insuring the flotilla boats might leave the companies open to prosecution for aiding a terrorist organization.<ref name="nyt28"/> In addition, Shurat HaDin sent a letter warning [[Inmarsat]], a satellite navigation company, that it could be open to legal charges for providing communications and navigation services to ships that are part of the flotilla.<ref>{{cite news |author=AFP |date=7 June 2011 |url=http://www.jordantimes.com/index.php?news=38232 |title=Israel group warns Inmarsat |work=The Jordan Times |accessdate=11 July 2011}}</ref>
Gisha, an Israeli not-for-profit organization whose stated goal is "to protect the freedom of movement of Palestinians, especially Gaza residents,"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gisha.org/content.asp?lang_id=en&p_id=5 |title=About Gisha |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726104951/http://www.gisha.org/index.php?intLanguage=2&intSiteSN=137&intItemId=107# |archivedate=26 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=11 July 2011 <!-- archived url --> |df=dmy-all }}</ref> criticized the focus on humanitarian aid by flotilla organizers and the Israeli government. Sari B ashi, Executive Director of Gisha, said "residents of Gaza are being deliberately reduced to recipients of humanitarian aid" and that there is "no shortage of food in Gaza, but economic recovery is blocked by sweeping restrictions on the movement of goods and people".<ref name="jp-takeitout">{{cite news |last=Lazaroff |first=Tovah |date=30 June 2011 |title='Don't bring food into Gaza – take it out' |url=http://www.jpost.com/DiplomacyAndPolitics/Article.aspx?id=227207 |work=Jerusalem Post |accessdate=7 July 2011}}<br />• {{cite web |date=29 June 2011 |url=http://www.gisha.org/index.php?intLanguage=2&intItemId=2050&intSiteSN=113 |title=As the flotilla approaches, Gisha warns: Gaza residents don't need more aid, they need to export and travel |publisher=Gisha |accessdate=5 July 2011}}</ref>
===Journalists=== {{Undue|section|date=July 2011}}
[[Israeli-Arab]] journalist [[Khaled Abu Toameh]], writing for the [[Gatestone Institute]], noted that "according to Palestinians living in the Gaza Strip, there is no shortage of basic foods",<ref name="Abu-Toameh-2011"/> and that "periodic shortage of medical supplies is often attributed to the ongoing power struggle between Hamas and Fatah, whose representatives in the West Bank are sometimes accused of withholding medicine as a way of punishing the Hamas government."<ref name="Abu-Toameh-2011"/> Abu Toameh questioned why, given this situation, the flotilla organizers did not plan to help Syrian and Libyan refugees, whose situation was worse, or to express solidarity with Saudi Arabian women who are being [[gender apartheid in Saudi Arabia|arrested for driving]] cars.<ref name="Abu-Toameh-2011"/>
Canada's ''[[National Post]]'' editorialized against the flotilla, calling it a "charade".<ref name="np-2011"/> It concluded that <blockquote>The real intention of the flotilla is to break the blockade and end Hamas' political isolation. There can be only one reason why anyone would consider such an outcome desirable: The absence of a blockade would allow the free passage of arms to the terror-embracing Hamas government, which has frequently demonstrated its goal of ending Israel's existence as a nation. Israel's blockade of Gaza is a direct consequence of attacks launched from within the territory. If flotilla participants really want to ease Gazans' isolation, they should encourage Hamas to acknowledge Israel's right to exist and to forswear terrorism.<ref name="np-2011"/> </blockquote>
''[[Pravda]]'' argued in favour of the flotilla, stating <blockquote>And so the world was forgetting Gaza. It forgot that the blockade was deemed illegal by the UN. They paid little attention to the complaints of people like Ilan Pappé, former professor of history at the [[University of Haifa]], "Israel uses genocidal policies in Gaza." The lack of UN action was left to pass blankly, whose commission investigating the massacre of Freedom Flotilla I was paralyzed (as though we do not know why). It is because of this forgetfulness that Freedom Flotilla 2 was ready to sail. Remember the tragedy in Gaza is far from over. The people there are still suffering a totally illegal and unjust blockade that has lasted five years. Humanity cannot continue allowing a city to be slowly strangled.<ref>{{cite web |last=Eça |first=Luiz |date=9 July 2011 |url=http://english.pravda.ru/history/09-07-2011/118438-Gaza_what_the_world_forgot-0/ |title=Gaza: what the world forgot |work=Pravda |accessdate=21 July 2011}}</ref> </blockquote>
===Other=== Businessmen from the Gaza Strip interviewed by ''[[Ynet]]'' said regarding the flotilla that the main problem was not importing goods into Gaza, as there was "no shortage of stock" in the territory, but the difficulty of exporting goods. However, they stressed that they were not opposed to the flotilla.<ref>{{cite news |last=Levy |first=Elior |date=1 July 2011 |title=Gazans unimpressed by flotilla |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4089709,00.html |work=Ynetnews |location=Tel Aviv |accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
Author [[Alice Walker]] announced that she will join the flotilla and published a letter in support of the Flotilla. The letter puts the flotilla in the context of the "followers of Gandhi," and the "Jewish civil rights activists" who stood side by side with blacks in America's South. In the letter, she also rebukes Benjamin Netanyahu policies, and those in the US who back them.<ref>{{cite news |last=Harman |first=Danna |date=23 June 2011 |title=Author Alice Walker to take part in Gaza flotilla, despite U.S. warning |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/author-alice-walker-to-take-part-in-gaza-flotilla-despite-u-s-warning-1.369262 |work=Haaretz |accessdate=7 July 2011}}</ref> Fellow author [[Howard Jacobson]] criticized Walker saying that her concern for setting the children of Gaza over the children of Israel does not justify the flotilla, and that she gives no convincing reason for partaking.<ref>{{cite news |author=JTA |date=24 June 2011 |title=UK writer slams Alice Walker for Gaza flotilla ride |url=http://www.jta.org/news/article/2011/06/24/3088287/acclaimed-novelist-criticizes-alice-walker-for-gaza-flotilla-participation |publisher=JTA |accessdate=10 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110627074207/http://www.jta.org/news/article/2011/06/24/3088287/acclaimed-novelist-criticizes-alice-walker-for-gaza-flotilla-participation |archivedate=27 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Philip Missfelder, foreign policy spokesman of the [[Christian Democratic Union (Germany)|Christian Democratic Union]] (CDU) and [[Christian Social Union of Bavaria|Christian Social Union]] (CSU) parties, the largest combined group of MPs in the [[German parliament]], said on 5 July that the so-called Gaza flotilla activists "endanger peace efforts" and their action is "part of the asymmetrical warfare against Israel." He added that their actions were "not about humanitarian help, rather a confrontation with Israel". He further stated that the activists were working against the goals of Germany and the Middle East Quartet. "I welcome that the Greek authorities have decisively intervened as some activists set sail without permission," he said.<ref name="braced"/>
[[Harvard University]] literature professor [[Ruth Wisse]] condemned the flotilla as a "kill-the-Jews flotilla", stating that its purpose was "to discredit the Israeli attempt to protect itself and to give Hamas a free hand amassing weapons to use against Israeli civilians".<ref>{{cite news |last=Twersky |first=Mordechai I. |date=4 July 2011 |title=Harvard professor assails 'kill-the-Jews flotilla' |url=http://www.jpost.com/VideoArticles/Video/Article.aspx?id=227881 |work=Jerusalem Post |accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref>
[[Christopher Hitchens]] condemned the flotilla for its cooperation with Hamas, noting Hamas' official and programmatic adoption of the [[antisemitic]] forgery ''[[The Protocols of the Elders of Zion]]'', its expression of outrage at the [[death of Osama bin Laden]], and its ties with [[Hezbollah]], [[al-Qaeda]] and the regimes of Syria and Iran. He also criticized the media for "soft-centred coverage" of the affair, suggesting that pointed questions should have been asked of the flotilla participants and that the title "activists" was an inaccurate and gratuitously positive label for the participants.<ref>{{cite web |last=Hitchins |first=Christopher |date=5 July 2011 |title=Christopher Hitchens: Some questions for the 'activists' aboard the Gaza flotilla |url=http://fullcomment.nationalpost.com/2011/07/05/christopher-hitchens-some-questions-for-the-%E2%80%9Cactivists%E2%80%9D-aboard-the-gaza-flotilla/ |work=National Post Full Comment |location=Toronto |accessdate=10 July 2011 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120708155459/http://fullcomment.nationalpost.com/2011/07/05/christopher-hitchens-some-questions-for-the-%E2%80%9Cactivists%E2%80%9D-aboard-the-gaza-flotilla/# |archive-date=8 July 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
According to [[Paul Murphy (Irish politician)|Paul Murphy]], Member of the [[European Parliament]] (MEP) and longtime Freedom Flotilla supporter, "The aim of the Flotilla is to break that siege by delivering vital medical supplies and construction material and to highlight the ongoing blockade and impact on the population."<ref>{{cite web|date=24 June 2011 |url=http://www.socialistworld.net/doc/5155 |title=Paul Murphy Socialist Party MEP joins 'Freedom Flotilla II' |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/603tZQbQo?url=http://www.socialistworld.net/doc/5155 |work=socialistworld.net |archivedate=10 July 2011 |deadurl=no |accessdate=10 July 2011 |df=dmy }}<br />• {{cite web|author=World Health Organization |date=20 June 2011 |title=Shortages of drugs and medical disposables in MoH Gaza |url=https://unispal.un.org/UNISPAL.NSF/0/B35E9E3AC0BFF630852578B5004B9C43 |work=UNISPAL Documents Collection |accessdate=5 July 2011 |quote=... the protracted period of low stocks is now deemed critical for the continued delivery of health care. }}</ref>
Four [[Nobel Peace]] Laureates, [[Mairead Maguire]], [[Jody Williams]], [[Shirin Ebadi]], and [[Rigoberta Menchú Tum]], wrote a letter to UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon "to urge you to use your good offices in support of the humanitarian needs of the people of Gaza....by appointing a representative to inspect and seal the cargo of the boats of the Freedom Flotilla II—thus assuring the Israeli government that the boats are carrying humanitarian supplies such as toys, medical supplies, cement and educational materials."<ref>{{cite web |title=Laureates to Ban Ki-moon: Safe passage for Gaza Flotilla |url=http://www.nobelwomensinitiative.org/home/article/laureates-support-freedom-flotilla |date=10 June 2011 <!--date of the open letter--> |location=Ottawa |publisher=Nobel Women's Initiative |accessdate=10 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721201740/http://www.nobelwomensinitiative.org/home/article/laureates-support-freedom-flotilla |archivedate=21 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
On 7 July 2011, [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]] linguistics professor [[Noam Chomsky]], wrote "Today the U.S. and Israel are vigorously seeking to block the flotilla. U.S. Secretary of State [[Hillary Clinton]] virtually authorized violence, stating that 'Israelis have the right to defend themselves' if flotillas 'try to provoke action by entering into Israeli waters' – that is, the territorial waters of Gaza, as if Gaza belonged to Israel. Greece agreed to prevent the boats from leaving (that is, those boats not already sabotaged) – though, unlike Clinton, Greece referred rightly to 'the maritime area of Gaza.' In January 2009, Greece had distinguished itself by refusing to permit U.S. arms to be shipped to Israel from Greek ports during the vicious U.S.-Israeli assault in Gaza. No longer an independent country in its current financial duress, Greece evidently cannot risk such unusual integrity."<ref>{{cite web |last=Chomsky |first=Noam |date=7 July 2011 |title=In Israel, a Tsunami Warning |url=http://www.truth-out.org/israel-tsunami-warning/1310042953 |work=Truthout |accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref>
===Reactions to Greek ban=== Greek President [[Karolos Papoulias]] later visited Israel, where Israeli President [[Shimon Peres]] told him: "I thank you very much for fulfilling the UN secretary general's guidelines and stopping the flotilla. Thank you for not allowing people interested in disturbing good order and international law from coming without supervision to Gaza, which is led by a terrorist group."<ref name="egypt"/>
Joshua Mitnick of the ''[[Christian Science Monitor]]'' reported that Greece's actions were the result of a growing relationship between Israel and Greece, including an offer of "generous military assistance", that started after Israeli–Turkish ties were damaged by the Gaza flotilla raid.<ref name="csm-greece"/>
